com.esri.mo2.ui.bean
Class Map

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.awt.Component
        |
        +--java.awt.Container
              |
              +--javax.swing.JComponent
                    |
                    +--javax.swing.JLayeredPane
                          |
                          +--com.esri.mo2.ui.bean.Map
All Implemented Interfaces:
Accessible, Canvas, ImageObserver, Map, MenuContainer, Serializable
public class Map
extends JLayeredPane
implements Map

A Map is a "Java Swing" component that displays geographic information on a canvas, and provides a way for users to interact with the data shown there. A Map consists of several component layers that are organized by the parent JLayeredPane class. These include a MapCanvas layer that appears at the bottom, zero or more AcetateLayers that can appear above the Mapcanvas, zero or more Tools that appear above that, and an EventLayer that appears above all the organized layers. You can also add any other Components to the Map - these will be placed above the EventLayer, so that MouseClicks will be passed to your component instead of to the Map.

The EventLayer is a transparent JComponent that is private to the Map and gathers all mouse events intended for user interaction with the map.

Tools are transparent components that can be used to display short-term graphic objects, such as rubberband shapes, or more simply, to react to mouse events by performing useful geographic functions.

The MapCanvas is an opaque component that has an ordered collection of map Layers. Layers can be added to the canvas by adding them to the Map's Layerset. The canvas displays the Data provided by the Layers, and optionally shows any selections as well as any labelling that also may be present. The canvas displays geographic objects for the duration of the application session - so it can be thought of as long-term. The canvas is double-buffered to reduce redraws.

AcetateLayers are transparent components that have a single associated map Layer, and are primarily used to animate data. You can have as many AcetateLayers as you need, however, there is a resource penalty for adding too many of them, also for trying to draw too much data. AcetateLayers are not double-buffered, thus each time the Map is redrawn, the data is redrawn once more.

You should be able to use the Map within an Integrated Development Environment, to easily build a Map-based application.

See Also:
Serialized Form

setMapUnit

public void setMapUnit(int unit)
Sets the map unit. Some common units are stored as static integers in the com.esri.mo2.util.Units class. The default map unit is UNKNOWN, which is a value of 7 in the Units class.

getMapTipText

public String getMapTipText(MouseEvent event)
Returns the MapTip text at a MouseEvent click location. This method first checks the current Tool if there is any MapTip text at the given location, if none is found or if there is no current Tool selected, each Layer in the Map is checked in order from top to bottom as seen within the TOC. The first non-null Tool or Layer MapTip text found is returned as the MapTip text for the given location.

You can over-ride this method to add text, or to provide new text altogether.

setExtent

public boolean setExtent(Envelope r)
change the map extent using the specified Envelope.

This will cause all Layers to be redrawn upon the Display, and, where a Layer is connected with a Remote FeatureClass, may cause a Layer to initiate data retrieval from a remote server.

Note: provided the specified Envelope is valid, it will be re-shaped to preserve the current Display's pixel window aspect ratio - calling code does not need to be concerned with this. If reshaping does occur, the centre of the specified rectangle will coincide with the reshaped rectangle, and the scale will be retained

If the new Envelope is no different from the current value of getExtent() then no drawing is initiated.

The coordinates used in Envelope depend upon the current coordinate system.

Specified by:
setExtent in interface Map
Parameters:
r - the new mapextent
Returns:
True, if drawing was initiated, False otherwise.
See Also:
Global.isValid(com.esri.mo2.cs.geom.Envelope)

getExtent

public Envelope getExtent()
Returns a copy of the current map extent corresponding to the canvas window.

Specified by:
getExtent in interface Canvas
Returns:
the canvas map extent

redraw

public void redraw()
cause the map to be redrawn, without changing the map's extent. This is similar to calling setExtent(getExtent()) except that redraw always redraws the map, while setExtent(getExtent()) will normally be ignored if the map size remains unchanged.

See Also:
setExtent(com.esri.mo2.cs.geom.Envelope), getExtent()

setExtentLimit

public void setExtentLimit(Envelope limit)
change the Map's extent limit. Once you set this property, future drawing of the Map is confined to the specified Envelope, and LayerExtensions associated with Layers in this Map will retrieve data within the confines of this property. You can switch off this behaviour by setting the extent limit property to null. You must redraw the Map to see the change caused by this property.

Specified by:
setExtentLimit in interface Map
Parameters:
limit - the new extent limit, or null == do not use an extent limit
See Also:
redraw()

getExtentLimit

public Envelope getExtentLimit()
Returns the Map's current extent limit. If this method returns a null, it indicates that the extent limiting behaviour has been switched off - which is the default when the software starts.

Specified by:
getExtentLimit in interface Map
Returns:
the extent limit
See Also:
setExtentLimit(com.esri.mo2.cs.geom.Envelope)

setCoordinateSystem

public void setCoordinateSystem(CoordinateSystem coordSystem)
Description copied from interface: Map
changes the coordinate system used to display data in this Map.

Typically, calling this method will result in changing the map unit and recalculating the map extent.

In the general case (from changing one coordinate system to another) setCoordinateSystem will try to recalculate the new map extent based upon the transformation implied between the two coordinate systems. But, if either the previous or the new map projection is null, the method cannot do the calculation, and will change the mapextent to being the full extent - to ensure something is shown.

If some particular extent for a new coordinate system is needed, setExtent method should be called after calling setCoordinateSystem method.

Specified by:
setCoordinateSystem in interface Map
Parameters:
coordSystem - the new CoordinateSystem, or null , if no CoordinateSystem

getLayer

public Layer getLayer(String layerName)
A helper method, returns a reference to a Layer for the given layer name. For convenience, the name of a sub-Layer inside a GroupLayer can consist a dot-separated list of names. For instance, if an ImageServerLayer named "MyServer" is present in the Map, and MyServer has a subLayer named "Cities", then the subLayer can be located by calling getLayer("MyServer.Cities"). For now, only one level of Grouplayer is supported. So, you cannot currently locate a subLayer named "GroupLayer.MyServer.Cities".

Specified by:
getLayer in interface Map
Parameters:
layerName - the name of the Layer to be obtained
Returns:
the Layer if found, null == not found

getLayer

public Layer getLayer(int index)
A helper method, returns a reference to a Layer in the top-level Layerset of this Map, at the given layer index. Only Layers within the Map's Layerset can be found this way - subLayers cannot be found this way.

Specified by:
getLayer in interface Map
See Also:
GroupLayer.layerAt(int), getLayer(String)

Returns:
an array of of Layer names

cancel

public void cancel()
Cancels all currently occuring data retrievals within the Datasets known to this Map.

Note: this method does not cancel the current rendering of datasets within the Map, it only affects datasets that obtain data from remote data sources such as from ArcIMS feature or image services, where the data is being retrieved in a separate thread. If an end-user wants to cancel the display of a large shapefile (for instance) then the technique for doing this is to change the visibility of the Layer (typically by clicking the corresponding checkbox within the Toc) or by changing the map extent - in both these cases, the current rendering will cease and the new rendering begins.

Note: This method may have undesired consequences on retrievals that are not related to this Map, but which are occuring in Datasets known to this Map. The Datasets *not* known to this Map will remain unaffected.

setAutoCursorManagement

public void setAutoCursorManagement(boolean enable)
enable/disable Cursor management. By default, whenever the Display is redrawn, a WaitingCursor will be displayed. In addition, whenever a Tool is selected, the Cursor of the Tool is displayed. Finally, the WaitingCursor is shown if you use the setWaitingCursor methods. All of these default behaviours can be enabled/disabled by calling this method. If you choose to disable, then you will need to subclass Map and handle Cursors yourself by overriding setSelectedTool, and possibly also adding a DisplayListener.

Parameters:
enable - true == accept default behaviour, false == otherwise

getAutoCursorManagement

public boolean getAutoCursorManagement()
Obtains the current Cursor management handling state.

Returns:
a boolean attribute - True == default behaviour, False == no Cursor management
See Also:
setAutoCursorManagement(boolean)

setWaiting

public void setWaiting(boolean waiting)
set the waiting Cursor in the Map when AutoCursorManagement is in operation based on the currently set wait cursor. You should call this method in pairs, first with parameter true to begin showing the waiting cursor, later with parameter false to return the cursor to normal. It is possible that other code will do the same so this method manages a counter of how many times the method has been called and switches back to the normal cursor only when the counter reaches zero. This method is ignored if AutoCursorManagement is not operating

Parameters:
waiting - true == set the cursor the waiting, false == set the cursor to the current selected Tool's cursor
See Also:
setAutoCursorManagement(boolean)

setWaitingCursor

public void setWaitingCursor(Cursor cursor)
set the wait cursor to be used in setWaiting

getWaitingCursor

public Cursor getWaitingCursor()
Returns the wait cursor to be used in setWaiting.

isWaiting

public boolean isWaiting()
determine if the waiting cursor has been set via setWaitingCursor

Returns:
true == waiting cursor counter > 0, false otherwise

setRefreshTime

public void setRefreshTime(int tm)
set the refresh time property.

By modifying this property, you can adjust the frequency that the map Display is rendered to the visual Component.

The value of this property is the number of milliseconds between the times that the map begins to redraw itself. This is occuring during periods of change, such as when a Layer begins rendering data that is streaming in from a remote Dataset.

Parameters:
tm - the number of milliseconds (ignored if < 20)

getRefreshTime

public int getRefreshTime()
Returns the value of the refresh time property.

Returns:
the current refresh time
See Also:
setRefreshTime(int)

getScale

public double getScale()
A convenience method for obtaining the current map scale as a ratio of map units / pixel (Map units per pixel). This is defined to be the Scale property of the PixelToWorldTransform property of this Map. This is not a "true scale" but it is the current scale used for determining scale dependencies.

Specified by:
getScale in interface Map
Returns:
the current map scale (for example: 0.0127463845638)

createMapPrinter

public MapPrinter createMapPrinter(Rectangle bounds)
Creates a MapPrinter object which captures the current state of the Map, such as MapExtent and Layers. To print a Map, you should first obtain a MapPrinter object. In your application code, then call the MapPrinter's print(graphics) method to perform the actual printing and pass the Graphics object into java.awt.print.Printable.print(graphics) method.

When creating a MapPrinter, you need to specify the Map's "Imageable Area" in printer units - this is usually measured in "printer points" (1/72 inch). The ImageableArea is a Rectangle that describes the size and location on paper of the printed Map. When your code calls the MapPrinter's print(Graphics) method, the units of the specified Graphics object will be assumed to be the same printer units.

Parameters:
bounds - the Rectangle specifying the size and location of the Map on the paper
Returns:
an object that can be used to print the Map
See Also:
Printable

addLayers

public void addLayers(Layer[] layers)
Adds several layers to the map using the following strategy:
  • any FeatureLayer having a feature type of point, will be added at the top.
  • any FeatureLayer having a feature type of line, will be inserted just above the first line layer (if any) that is already in the Map.
  • any FeatureLayer having a feature type of polygon, will be inserted just above the first polygon layer (if any) that is already in the Map.
  • all other types of Layer, such as images, will be added at the bottom of the Map

Parameters:
layers - an array of zero or more layers to be added to the map
